Smoothness of the future and past trapped sets in Kerr-Newman-Taub-NUT spacetimes

Claudio F. Paganini†, and Marius A. Oancea† claudio.paganini@aei.mpg.de marius.oancea@aei.mpg.de †Albert Einstein Institute, Am Mühlenberg 1, D-14476 Potsdam, Germany
(Date: March 8, 2024 File:Kerrnullgeod.tex)
Abstract.

We consider the sets of future/past trapped null geodesics in the exterior region of a sub-extremal Kerr-Newman-Taub-NUT spacetime. We show that from the point of view of any timelike observer outside of such a black hole, trapping can be understood as two smooth sets of spacelike directions on the celestial sphere of the observer.

  2. 2 The Kerr-Newman-Taub-NUT Spacetime
  3. 3 Geodesic Equations

  6. A

1. Introduction

The trapped sets on the celestial sphere are closely related to the notion of black hole shadows. The shadow of the black hole is defined as the innermost trajectory on which light from a background source passing a black hole can reach the observer. The past trapped set of null geodesics through a point thus corresponds to the boundary of the black hole shadow. The first discussion of the shadow in Schwarzschild spacetimes can be found in [19], and, for extremal Kerr at infinity, it was later calculated in [1]. Analyzing the shadows of black holes is of direct physical interest as there is hope for the Event Horizon Telescope to be able to resolve the black hole in the center of the Milky Way well enough so that one can compare it to the predictions from theoretical calculations, see for example [6]. This perspective has led to a number of advancements in the theoretical treatment of black hole shadows in recent years [4, 7, 8, 9, 11, 13].

Our main contribution in the present paper is the proof of Theorem 9 which is the first rigorous proof of the observations in [8]. The significance of Theorem 9 is that we prove that for any subextremal Kerr-Newman-Taub-NUT spacetime, including Schwarzschild, the past and the future trapped sets at any regular point in the exterior region are smooth closed curves on the celestial sphere of any observer. We would like to stress that Theorem 9 therefore describes a property of trapping which does not change when going from Schwarzschild to Kerr-Newman-Taub-NUT.

Beyond its relevance for the discussion of black hole shadows the result is also of interest with respect to decay estimates for fields in the exterior region of Kerr black holes. Trapping is one of the biggest obstacle to prove such decay results. The area of trapping changes substantially when going from Schwarzschild, where it is restricted to one fix radius, to Kerr where the area of trapping covers a finite range of radii. This makes it a lot harder to prove decay in Kerr than it is for Schwarzschild. This difficulty was only recently overcome in [5] for all subextremal Kerr space times. To study the decay of fields in Kerr, it is thus important to understand which properties of trapping survive when going from Schwarzschild to Kerr.

The main result of the present work will be used in our upcoming work [15] where we discuss the maximum amount of information that can be extracted from the shape of the shadows. This paper is an extraction of the novel material contained in our lecture notes [17] with an extension to the Kerr-Newman-Taub-NUT class of spacetimes.

Overview of this paper

In section 2 we collect some background on the Kerr-Newman-Taub-NUT spacetime. In section 3 we discuss the geodesic equations in its separated form. In section 4 we prove our main Theorem on the topological structure of the past and future trapped sets.

2. The Kerr-Newman-Taub-NUT Spacetime

The Kerr-Newman-Taub-NUT family of spacetimes describes axially symmetric and stationary black hole solutions to the Einstein-Maxwell field equations. We use Boyer-Lindquist (BL) coordinates (t,r,ϕ,θ𝑡𝑟italic-ϕ𝜃t,r,\phi,\theta), which have the property that the metric components are independent of ϕitalic-ϕ\phi and t𝑡t. The metric has the form [10]:

where

Σ=r2+(l+a​cos⁡θ)2,Σsuperscript𝑟2superscript𝑙𝑎𝜃2\Sigma=r^{2}+(l+a\cos\theta)^{2}, (2.2)

Δ​(r)=r2−2​M​r+a2−l2+Q2.Δ𝑟superscript𝑟22𝑀𝑟superscript𝑎2superscript𝑙2superscript𝑄2\Delta(r)=r^{2}-2Mr+a^{2}-l^{2}+Q^{2}. (2.4)

Here, M𝑀M is the mass, a𝑎a is the angular momentum, Q2=Qe2+Qm2superscript𝑄2subscriptsuperscript𝑄2𝑒subscriptsuperscript𝑄2𝑚Q^{2}=Q^{2}_{e}+Q^{2}_{m} is the charge, and l𝑙l is the NUT parameter. Also, there is another parameter, C, which was first introduced by Manko and Ruiz [14]. This parameter modifies the singularities on the rotation axis, introduced by the Taub-NUT parameter l𝑙l. For a discussion of the physical nature of these parameters and the nature of the singularities in these spacetimes see [8], and for a discussion of the rotation axis in the case l≠0𝑙0l\neq 0 see [16]. In our present work we will stay away from any irregular points in these spacetimes, in particular those that arise for l≠0𝑙0l\neq 0 on the rotation axis.
The zeros of Δ​(r)Δ𝑟\Delta(r) are given by:

In the present work we are only interested in the exterior region of the black hole spacetime, hence r∈(r+,∞)𝑟subscript𝑟r\in(r_{+},\infty). For our considerations it is useful to introduce an orthonormal tetrad. A convenient choice is:

This frame is a natural choice as the principal null directions can be written in the simple form e0±e1plus-or-minussubscript𝑒0subscript𝑒1e_{0}\pm e_{1}.

3. Geodesic Equations

We now focus our attention on null geodesics. The constants of motion for geodesics in Kerr-Newman-Taub-NUT spacetimes are the mass, which we set equal to zero, the energy, the angular momentum with respect to the rotation axis of the black hole and Carter’s constant [2]:

E𝐸\displaystyle E =−(∂t)ν⁡γ˙ν,absentsuperscriptsubscript𝑡𝜈subscript˙𝛾𝜈\displaystyle=-(\partial_{t})^{\nu}\dot{\gamma}_{\nu}, (3.1b)

K𝐾\displaystyle K =σμ​ν​γ˙μ​γ˙ν,absentsubscript𝜎𝜇𝜈superscript˙𝛾𝜇superscript˙𝛾𝜈\displaystyle=\sigma_{\mu\nu}\dot{\gamma}^{\mu}\dot{\gamma}^{\nu}, (3.1d)

σμ​ν=Σ​((e1)μ​(e1)ν+(e2)μ​(e2)ν)−(l+a​cos⁡(θ))2​gμ​νsubscript𝜎𝜇𝜈Σsubscriptsubscript𝑒1𝜇subscriptsubscript𝑒1𝜈subscriptsubscript𝑒2𝜇subscriptsubscript𝑒2𝜈superscript𝑙𝑎𝜃2subscript𝑔𝜇𝜈\sigma_{\mu\nu}=\Sigma((e_{1})_{\mu}(e_{1})_{\nu}+(e_{2})_{\mu}(e_{2})_{\nu})-(l+a\cos(\theta))^{2}g_{\mu\nu} (3.2)

The constants of motion can be used to decouple the geodesic equation to a set of four first order ODEs, e.g. [3, p. 242]:

For the radial and the angular equations we have:

R​(r,E,Lz,K)𝑅𝑟𝐸subscript𝐿𝑧𝐾\displaystyle R(r,E,L_{z},K) =E2​R​(r,1,LE,KE),absentsuperscript𝐸2𝑅𝑟1subscript𝐿𝐸subscript𝐾𝐸\displaystyle=E^{2}R(r,1,L_{E},K_{E}), (3.4)

where LE=Lz/Esubscript𝐿𝐸subscript𝐿𝑧𝐸L_{E}=L_{z}/E and KE=K/E2subscript𝐾𝐸𝐾superscript𝐸2K_{E}=K/E^{2}. One of the most important features of geodesic motion in black hole spacetimes is the possibility of trapping. A geodesic is called trapped if its motion is bounded in a spatially compact region away from the horizon. In Kerr-Newman-Taub-NUT this corresponds to the geodesics motion being bounded in the r𝑟r direction. In [8] it was shown that one can obtain a parametrization of the conserved quantities for trapped null geodesics in terms of their radial location:

KE=16​r2​Δ​(r)(Δ′​(r))2|r=rt​r​a​p​p,subscript𝐾𝐸evaluated-at16superscript𝑟2Δ𝑟superscriptsuperscriptΔ′𝑟2𝑟subscript𝑟𝑡𝑟𝑎𝑝𝑝\displaystyle K_{E}=\left.\frac{16r^{2}\Delta(r)}{(\Delta^{\prime}(r))^{2}}\right|_{r=r_{trapp}}, (3.6a)
a​LE=(Σ+a​χ)−4​r​Δ​(r)Δ′​(r)|r=rt​r​a​p​p,𝑎subscript𝐿𝐸Σ𝑎𝜒evaluated-at4𝑟Δ𝑟superscriptΔ′𝑟𝑟subscript𝑟𝑡𝑟𝑎𝑝𝑝\displaystyle aL_{E}=\left.(\Sigma+a\chi)-\frac{4r\Delta(r)}{\Delta^{\prime}(r)}\right|_{r=r_{trapp}}, (3.6b)

where Δ′​(r)=2​r−2​MsuperscriptΔ′𝑟2𝑟2𝑀\Delta^{\prime}(r)=2r-2M is the partial derivative of Δ​(r)Δ𝑟\Delta(r) with respect to r𝑟r. Further the following inequality for the area of trapping was derived in [8]:

(4​r​Δ​(r)−Σ​Δ′​(r))2≤16​a2​r2​Δ​(r)​sin2⁡(θ).superscript4𝑟Δ𝑟ΣsuperscriptΔ′𝑟216superscript𝑎2superscript𝑟2Δ𝑟superscript2𝜃(4r\Delta(r)-\Sigma\Delta^{\prime}(r))^{2}\leq 16a^{2}r^{2}\Delta(r)\sin^{2}(\theta). (3.7)

Further it was shown that all spherical null geodesics in the exterior region are unstable and therefore no non-spherical trapped null geodesics can exist in this region. Thus, the above set is complete, in the sense that it includes all trapped null geodesics that exist.

4. Trapping as a Set of Directions

In this section we will introduce a formal framework for our discussion. This allows us to give a more technical discussion of the trapped sets in Kerr-Newman-Taub-NUT spacetimes.

4.1. Framework

First we have to introduce the basic framework and notations. Let ℳℳ\mathcal{M} be a smooth manifold with Lorenzian metric g𝑔g. At any point p𝑝p in ℳℳ\mathcal{M} it is possible to find an orthonormal basis (e0,e1,e2,e3)subscript𝑒0subscript𝑒1subscript𝑒2subscript𝑒3(e_{0},e_{1},e_{2},e_{3}) for the tangent space, with e0subscript𝑒0e_{0} being the timelike direction. It is sufficient to treat only future directed null geodesics as the past directed ones are identical up to a sign flip in the parametrization and we are only interested in global properties of the null geodesics. The tangent vector to any future pointing null geodesic can be written as:

γ˙​(k|p)|p=α​(e0+k1​e1+k2​e2+k3​e3)evaluated-at˙𝛾evaluated-at𝑘𝑝𝑝𝛼subscript𝑒0subscript𝑘1subscript𝑒1subscript𝑘2subscript𝑒2subscript𝑘3subscript𝑒3\dot{\gamma}(k|_{p})|_{p}=\alpha(e_{0}+k_{1}e_{1}+k_{2}e_{2}+k_{3}e_{3}) (4.1)

where α=−g​(γ˙,e0)𝛼𝑔˙𝛾subscript𝑒0\alpha=-g(\dot{\gamma},e_{0}) and k=(k1,k2,k3)𝑘subscript𝑘1subscript𝑘2subscript𝑘3k=(k_{1},k_{2},k_{3}) satisfies |k|2=1superscript𝑘21|k|^{2}=1, hence k∈S2𝑘superscript𝑆2k\in S^{2}. The geodesic is independent of the scaling of the tangent vector as this corresponds to an affine reparametrization for the null geodesic. We will therefore set α=1𝛼1\alpha=1 in the following discussion.

Remark 1.

We will refer to the S2superscript𝑆2S^{2} as the celestial sphere of a timelike observer at p𝑝p, whose tangent vector is given by e0subscript𝑒0e_{0}, along the lines of e.g. [18, p.8].

Given we fixed a starting point p𝑝p and a tangent vector (4.1) by choosing k𝑘k and α𝛼\alpha, there exists a unique solution to the geodesic equation with this initial data. Thus, we make the following definition:

Definition 2.

Let γ​(k|p)𝛾evaluated-at𝑘𝑝\gamma(k|_{p}) denote a null geodesic through p𝑝p whose tangent vector at p𝑝p is given by equation (4.1).

Suppose now that ℳℳ\mathcal{M} is the exterior region of a black hole spacetime with a complete future and past null infinity ℐ±superscriptℐplus-or-minus\mathcal{I}^{\pm} and a boundary given by the future and past event horizon ℋ+∪ℋ−superscriptℋsuperscriptℋ\mathcal{H}^{+}\cup\mathcal{H}^{-}. We can then define the following sets on S2superscript𝑆2S^{2} at every point p𝑝p.

The future escaping set: Ωℐ+​(p):={k∈S2|γ​(k|p)∩ℐ+≠∅}assignsubscriptΩsuperscriptℐ𝑝conditional-set𝑘superscript𝑆2𝛾evaluated-at𝑘𝑝superscriptℐ\Omega_{\mathcal{I}^{+}}(p):=\{k\in S^{2}|\gamma(k|_{p})\cap\mathcal{I}^{+}\neq\emptyset\} .
The future trapped set: 𝕋+​(p):={k∈S2|γ​(k|p)∩(ℋ+∪ℐ+)=∅}assignsubscript𝕋𝑝conditional-set𝑘superscript𝑆2𝛾evaluated-at𝑘𝑝superscriptℋsuperscriptℐ\mathbb{T}_{+}(p):=\{k\in S^{2}|\gamma(k|_{p})\cap(\mathcal{H}^{+}\cup\mathcal{I}^{+})=\emptyset\}.
The past infalling set: Ωℋ−​(p):={k∈S2|γ​(k|p)∩ℋ−≠∅}assignsubscriptΩsuperscriptℋ𝑝conditional-set𝑘superscript𝑆2𝛾evaluated-at𝑘𝑝superscriptℋ\Omega_{\mathcal{H}^{-}}(p):=\{k\in S^{2}|\gamma(k|_{p})\cap\mathcal{H}^{-}\neq\emptyset\}.
The past escaping set: Ωℐ−​(p):={k∈S2|γ​(k|p)∩ℐ−≠∅}assignsubscriptΩsuperscriptℐ𝑝conditional-set𝑘superscript𝑆2𝛾evaluated-at𝑘𝑝superscriptℐ\Omega_{\mathcal{I}^{-}}(p):=\{k\in S^{2}|\gamma(k|_{p})\cap\mathcal{I}^{-}\neq\emptyset\}.

We further define the trapped set to be:

Definition 4.

The trapped set: 𝕋​(p):=𝕋+​(p)∩𝕋−​(p)assign𝕋𝑝subscript𝕋𝑝subscript𝕋𝑝\mathbb{T}(p):=\mathbb{T}_{+}(p)\cap\mathbb{T}_{-}(p).

The region of trapping in the manifold ℳℳ\mathcal{M} is then given by:

Definition 5.

Region of trapping: 𝒜:={p∈ℳ|𝕋​(p)≠∅}assign𝒜conditional-set𝑝ℳ𝕋𝑝\mathcal{A}:=\{p\in\mathcal{M}|\mathbb{T}(p)\neq\emptyset\}.

Definition 6.

We refer to the set Ωℋ−​(p)∪𝕋−​(p)subscriptΩsuperscriptℋ𝑝subscript𝕋𝑝\Omega_{\mathcal{H}^{-}}(p)\cup\mathbb{T}_{-}(p) as the shadow of the black hole.

Suppose we place light sources close to infinity and thus certainly further out than the observer itself. The observer in the exterior region can then only observe light from such background sources along directions k∈Ωℐ−​(p)𝑘subscriptΩsuperscriptℐ𝑝k\in\Omega_{\mathcal{I}^{-}}(p) and hence the domain on the observers celestial sphere that belongs to the shadow is always going to be black. Therefore in any practical purposes an observer can only obtain information about the boundary of the shadow. In the the next section we will proof that this boundary is given exactly by 𝕋−​(p)subscript𝕋𝑝\mathbb{T}_{-}(p).

4.2. The trapped sets

We will now discuss the properties of the sets 𝕋±​(p)subscript𝕋plus-or-minus𝑝\mathbb{T}_{\pm}(p) in Kerr-Newman-Taub-NUT. Note that the equations of motion for r𝑟r (3.3c) and θ𝜃\theta (3.3d) have two solutions that differ only by a sign for a fixed combination of E,Lz,K𝐸subscript𝐿𝑧𝐾E,L_{z},K. Therefore we know that the trapped sets will have a reflection symmetry across the k1=0subscript𝑘10k_{1}=0 and the k2=0subscript𝑘20k_{2}=0 planes. A sign change in k2subscript𝑘2k_{2} maps both sets 𝕋±​(p)subscript𝕋plus-or-minus𝑝\mathbb{T}_{\pm}(p) to themselves, while a sign flip in k1subscript𝑘1k_{1} maps 𝕋+​(p)subscript𝕋𝑝\mathbb{T}_{+}(p) to 𝕋−​(p)subscript𝕋𝑝\mathbb{T}_{-}(p) and vice versa. We start by analyzing the sets for points of symmetry

Definition 7.

A Point of symmetry is a point for which there exists a one parameter family of diffeomorphism with closed orbits, which all leave the point itself invariant.

Lemma 8.

The sets 𝕋+​(p)subscript𝕋𝑝\mathbb{T}_{+}(p) and 𝕋−​(p)subscript𝕋𝑝\mathbb{T}_{-}(p) are circles on the celestial sphere of any timelike observer at any regular point of symmetry in the exterior region of any subextremal Kerr-Newman-Taub-NUT spacetime.

Proof.

To determine the structure of 𝕋±​(p)subscript𝕋plus-or-minus𝑝\mathbb{T}_{\pm}(p) we observe that when we pick a future/past trapped direction and apply the diffeomorphism, the spacial directions of T​M|pevaluated-at𝑇𝑀𝑝TM|_{p} are rotated around the vector pointing along the axis left invariant by the diffeomorphism. Therefore the future/past trapped direction traces proper circles on the celestial sphere. Therefore the future and past trapped set at such a point p𝑝p always correspond to a collection of circles independent of the details of the manifold or the location of p𝑝p therein. We are now going to show that in the spacetimes under consideration here 𝕋±​(p)subscript𝕋plus-or-minus𝑝\mathbb{T}_{\pm}(p) consist of exactly one circle. For the spherically symmetric spacetimes this is a well known fact. For an observer located at a regular point on the rotation axis of Kerr-Newmann-Taub-NUT black holes we can apply the following argument. Note that for l≠0𝑙0l\neq 0 and a≠0𝑎0a\neq 0 we have to choose C=±1𝐶plus-or-minus1C=\pm 1 for the procedure to apply to the regular part of the rotation axis in these cases. For all other values of C𝐶C both parts of the rotation axis are singular. Hence the discussion here does not apply to those cases.
From equation (3.3d) it is clear that null geodesics that can reach the rotation axis have to have Lz=0subscript𝐿𝑧0L_{z}=0. For the case Lz=0subscript𝐿𝑧0L_{z}=0 it is clear that there exists only one value of KEt​r​a​p​p​(Lz=0)superscriptsubscript𝐾𝐸𝑡𝑟𝑎𝑝𝑝subscript𝐿𝑧0K_{E}^{trapp}(L_{z}=0) and rt​r​a​p​p​(Lz=0)subscript𝑟𝑡𝑟𝑎𝑝𝑝subscript𝐿𝑧0r_{trapp}(L_{z}=0). To treat an observer on the rotation axis we need to introduce a new coordinate system which covers the axis. We will use Cartesian coordinates (t,x,y,z)𝑡𝑥𝑦𝑧(t,x,y,z), which are related to the Boyer-Lindquist coordinates (t,r,θ,ϕ)𝑡𝑟𝜃italic-ϕ(t,r,\theta,\phi) by the following relations:

Theorem 9.

The sets 𝕋+​(p)subscript𝕋𝑝\mathbb{T}_{+}(p) and 𝕋−​(p)subscript𝕋𝑝\mathbb{T}_{-}(p) are smooth curves on the celestial sphere of any timelike observer at any point in the exterior region of any subextremal Kerr-Newman-Taub-NUT spacetime.

Since p∈𝒜𝑝𝒜p\in\mathcal{A} we have that xm​i​n​(θ​(p))<r​(p)<xm​a​x​(θ​(p))subscript𝑥𝑚𝑖𝑛𝜃𝑝𝑟𝑝subscript𝑥𝑚𝑎𝑥𝜃𝑝x_{min}(\theta(p))<r(p)<x_{max}(\theta(p)). Case 3.

In the special case when r​(p)=xm​a​x​(θ​(p))𝑟𝑝subscript𝑥𝑚𝑎𝑥𝜃𝑝r(p)=x_{max}(\theta(p)) or r​(p)=xm​i​n​(θ​(p))𝑟𝑝subscript𝑥𝑚𝑖𝑛𝜃𝑝r(p)=x_{min}(\theta(p)) the functions ρ1subscript𝜌1\rho_{1} and ρ2subscript𝜌2\rho_{2}, which describe 𝕋±​(p)subscript𝕋plus-or-minus𝑝\mathbb{T}_{\pm}(p), do reach ρ=π/2𝜌𝜋2\rho=\pi/2 at ψ=3​π/2𝜓3𝜋2\psi=3\pi/2 (for r​(p)=xm​a​x​(θ​(p))𝑟𝑝subscript𝑥𝑚𝑎𝑥𝜃𝑝r(p)=x_{max}(\theta(p))) or ψ=π/2𝜓𝜋2\psi=\pi/2 (for r​(p)=xm​i​n​(θ​(p))𝑟𝑝subscript𝑥𝑚𝑖𝑛𝜃𝑝r(p)=x_{min}(\theta(p))) respectively. However since in these cases we have that

d2d​ψ2​(h​(x​(ψ)))=0superscript𝑑2𝑑superscript𝜓2ℎ𝑥𝜓0\frac{d^{2}}{d\psi^{2}}(h(x(\psi)))=0 (4.20)

the two sets meet at this point tangentially and do not cross over into the other hemisphere.

Together with Lemma 8 this concludes the proof. ∎

Remark 10.

In [8] it was observed that ρm​a​xsubscript𝜌𝑚𝑎𝑥\rho_{max} of 𝕋+​(p)subscript𝕋𝑝\mathbb{T}_{+}(p) always corresponds to the trapped geodesic with xm​i​n​(θ​(p))subscript𝑥𝑚𝑖𝑛𝜃𝑝x_{min}(\theta(p)) and ρm​i​nsubscript𝜌𝑚𝑖𝑛\rho_{min} of 𝕋+​(p)subscript𝕋𝑝\mathbb{T}_{+}(p) always corresponds to the trapped geodesic with xm​a​x​(θ​(p))subscript𝑥𝑚𝑎𝑥𝜃𝑝x_{max}(\theta(p)) . When p𝑝p is outside the region of trapping h​(x)|xm​a​xevaluated-atℎ𝑥subscript𝑥𝑚𝑎𝑥h(x)|_{x_{max}} is a local maximum of h​(x​(ψ))ℎ𝑥𝜓h(x(\psi)) (as a function of ψ𝜓\psi) and h​(x)|xm​i​nevaluated-atℎ𝑥subscript𝑥𝑚𝑖𝑛h(x)|_{x_{min}} is a local minimum of h​(x​(ψ))ℎ𝑥𝜓h(x(\psi)). When p𝑝p is between the region of trapping and the horizon h​(x)|xm​a​xevaluated-atℎ𝑥subscript𝑥𝑚𝑎𝑥h(x)|_{x_{max}} is a local minimum of h​(x​(ψ))ℎ𝑥𝜓h(x(\psi)) and h​(x)|xm​i​nevaluated-atℎ𝑥subscript𝑥𝑚𝑖𝑛h(x)|_{x_{min}} is a local maximum of h​(x​(ψ))ℎ𝑥𝜓h(x(\psi)). Since outside 𝕋+​(p)subscript𝕋𝑝\mathbb{T}_{+}(p) is always described by ρ2​(ψ)subscript𝜌2𝜓\rho_{2}(\psi) and inside by ρ1​(ψ)subscript𝜌1𝜓\rho_{1}(\psi), ρm​i​nsubscript𝜌𝑚𝑖𝑛\rho_{min} then always corresponds to xm​i​nsubscript𝑥𝑚𝑖𝑛x_{min} and ρm​a​xsubscript𝜌𝑚𝑎𝑥\rho_{max} always corresponds to xm​a​xsubscript𝑥𝑚𝑎𝑥x_{max}. This also holds for p∈𝒜𝑝𝒜p\in\mathcal{A}. For 𝕋−​(p)subscript𝕋𝑝\mathbb{T}_{-}(p) the correspondence is switched.

Remark 11.

We have only proved Theorem 9 for one standard observer at any particular point. However since any other observer at this point is related to the standard observer by a Lorentz transformation and the Lorentz transformations act as conformal transformations on the celestial sphere [18, p.14], the Theorem indeed holds for any observer. In [7] the quantitative effect on the shape of the shadow of boosts in different directions are discussed.

Remark 12.

The parametrization for the trapped set on the celestial sphere of any standard observer in [8, 9] was derived for a much more general class of spacetimes. Therefore Theorem 9 might actually hold for these cases as well. However this is beyond the scope of this paper.

From Theorem 9 we immediately get the following Corollary:

Corollary 13.

For any observer at any regular point p𝑝p in the exterior region of a subextremal Kerr-Newman-Taub-NUT spacetime away from the axis of symmetry we have that for any k∈𝕋+​(p)𝑘subscript𝕋𝑝k\in\mathbb{T}_{+}(p) and any ϵ>0italic-ϵ0\epsilon>0

  • •

    Bϵ​(k)∩Ωℋ+​(p)≠∅subscript𝐵italic-ϵ𝑘subscriptΩsuperscriptℋ𝑝B_{\epsilon}(k)\cap\Omega_{\mathcal{H}^{+}}(p)\neq\emptyset

  • •

    Bϵ​(k)∩Ωℐ+​(p)≠∅subscript𝐵italic-ϵ𝑘subscriptΩsuperscriptℐ𝑝B_{\epsilon}(k)\cap\Omega_{\mathcal{I}^{+}}(p)\neq\emptyset.

So if we interpret the celestial sphere as initial data space for null geodesics starting at p𝑝p, the Corollary is a coordinate independent formulation of the fact that trapping in the exterior region of subextremal Kerr-Newman-Taub-NUT black holes is unstable.

5. Conclusion

Despite the fact that trapping in a Kerr-Newman-Taub-NUT spacetime is much more complicated than in Schwarzschild, we showed in the present work that the topological structure of the future and past trapped set at any point in the exterior region in Kerr-Newman-Taub-NUT is in fact simple and identical to the situation in Schwarzschild. Even though the qualitative features of 𝕋±​(p)subscript𝕋plus-or-minus𝑝\mathbb{T}_{\pm}(p) do not change under a change of parameters, the quantitative features do.
In [11, 13] it is discussed what information can be read of from the shadow at infinity. For points inside the manifold as considered in this work, this question will be answered in our upcoming paper [15]. The here presented result will be the foundation for our upcoming work [15].
